As a longtime executive recruiter in Silicon Valley, now happily retired, I‚Äôd like to point out that the clue for CIO (104 Down) is not quite correct. A Chief Information Officer (CIO) can be, and almost always is, an exec in *any* large company, not just tech companies, because all large companies have internal information systems, and the person responsible for them is usually a C-level executive called a CIO. This person, for example, would be the person to lead an overhaul of the company‚Äôs internal hardware and software systems - including payroll and financial planning software, for example. 

On the other hand, a ‚ÄúCTO‚Äù could be a good answer to the clue  ‚Äútech company exec‚Äù because it‚Äôs generally the case that *only* technology companies have Chief Technology Officers. That‚Äôs because a CTO‚Äôs do not concern themselves with the company‚Äôs internal systems, but rather lead the company‚Äôs research, development and possibly go-to-market strategy of their proprietary technology. The CTO of a semiconductor company, for example, would typically have a solid background in semiconductor engineering and manufacturing, since that is the ‚Äútech‚Äù the company is selling. Don‚Äôt ask them what payroll system the company uses!

A better clue for CIO would be something like: ‚Äútop exec in charge of internal systems‚Äù 

That‚Äôs a long-winded explanation, but hopefully now you all know the difference between a CIO and a CTO. I think the puzzle-makers were a bit confused about that.

"Vexillologist" was interesting to me. The original vexille was the standard carried by a Roman legion, and could also refer to the soldier who carried it into battle. That was a very important job, as a unit that had their flag captured could be subject to decimation. Napoleon gave his regiments each a gold eagle as a standard, and when the monarchy was restored, the first order of business was to destroy all the eagles. Lastly, if you've seen "Triumph of the Will," you will note that the banners at Nuremberg are almost identical to the original Roman vexilles.

Finished in about a third of my average Sunday time. Not surprised to see the comments are overwhelmingly in favor of how ridiculously easy the NYT puzzles have become. Seems like a race to the bottom no matter where you look these days.

This weekend was, for me, a vivid illustration of the total subjectivity of the solving experience. My longest time was Friday, almost double my normal solving time, though xwstats.com rated it as of Average difficulty. Today's puzzle, rated Very Easy, was close to Friday's time, well over my usual Sunday solve time. 

On the other hand, yesterday's, rated Hard, I solved in a fraction of the time, half my recent and a third my cumulative Saturday averages. 

I find that being unfamiliar with a single pop or classical reference can make the difference. However, today I got all those. My sole error was the double one @Dave mentions, having MaN and MeN where it should have been MEN and MAN. I caught these quite late in my flyspecking, when I realized KaBAB was probably KEBAB and OLe could be OLA.

It would have take even longer had I given in to the temptation to check the spelling of several proper names as I came across them. But I was determined to reconsider every answer at least once before resorting to that. Hey, I have to exercise willpower for something in my life.

And one more puzzle find. I'm sure a lot of us had done this one. A Sunday from January 19, 2023 by Rich Katz with the title: "The final frontier." I used to exercise more than anyone I knew, except for a few freaks that I heard about more than knew.

I've had been long distance running since the early Carter administration, and in my 50s finally took the plunge and went for a marathon.  Then another, and another...

Then came prostate surgery, and I never really came back from that.  I think I should have been able to, but I just didn't have that fire in my heart any longer.  Maybe the prostate is what provides the "fire in the heart".

So my exercising became more routine--some workout routines provided by Silver Sneakers.  And that was fine until my back started hurting so much I couldn't stand for 15 minutes, let alone exercise for 45.  Or maybe I could have.  I do know that it was quite painful, more than just the demands of the exercise (I was doing workouts rated as "hard").

Physical therapy and assorted cortisone injections and nerve ablations later, I'm better but all my momentum is gone.

So now I dread going to the doctor because I know she'll ask me if I'm exercising. 

Does this count as "interacting with people"?

@Francis

Vigorous walking is enough to provide huge benefits.

@Francis
I feel your pain, Francis. The body bounces back more slowly, and possibly not as high, every day. I'm watching a very old friend struggle with recent cognitive decline, and it's tough. I can see his frustration, and there's very little I can do to help. I'll be lucky if I get to be in his shoes, but I'm not looking forward to all of it. 

From what I can tell here, you are keeping it together, and I wish you the best. But even the phrase "keeping it together" implies that we need to somehow manage everything, and I'm not so sure that's the goal. Letting go of responsibility and performance expectations and allowing oneself to age seems to be the goal, but I'm not so sure how I'll feel when my time comes.

There was a book we read in high school "Flowers for Algernon", later made into the movie "Charlie".  It might be classified as very modest science fiction.

The general idea is that a person of very limited intelligence is treated with an experimental procedure which makes his intelligence bloom to Leonardo da Vinci levels.

But then he comes back down again.  And he knows he's coming down.

I guess that's a pretty good description of the arc of a lot of lives, if one lives long enough.

That's a great line from the Rollings Stones when they were, what, 23?  Utterly true, but...how could they know?

A change to your routine may help your (understandable) bad mood that you mentioned the other day.  Pilates is another great suggestion, but if you'd like to try swimming, I have a few suggestions to help with the logistics.

In addition to your gym bag, get one of those flimsy drawstring-type backpacks that you can put in your main bag.  Your towel and everything you need to shower can go in that, and you can carry it out to the pool area so you can go directly to the shower from there.

Have a plastic bag in your main bag, so when you get back to your locker, you can put your wet stuff in that.  

It will be like second nature once you do it for a few weeks.  I promise.

commentBody:

@Francis
I hear ya!
I was getting so upset about my difficulties (esp word-finding) that I got a referral to "The Mind Center" from my PCP.  Had to wait 6 months for the 90-minute assessment date, then had a raft of tests and screenings.  
The conclusion:  normal issues of ageing.  In fact, I was scoring quite high on scales, but the geriatrician called me out for "holding [myself] to a high standard."  (A nice way to say 'perfectionist.")  So I am trying to relax a bit more, which actually helps.  Continuing to walk; reading challenging books; playing card games, solving puzzles, writing.  Still can't get Left/Right, still screwing up my quilt blocks, but Oh Well.  What are the alternatives?

To me, you seem pretty sharp.

@Mean Old Lady

üòÄ Very nice!

I think I've come to accept that in most respects I am not abnormal.

So the complaints I have, which I might regard at moderate or even severe at times, are actually quite mild.

@SBK

Circle of life.

I feel quite privileged to be old, at least when I'm not entirely sober.

I once mentioned to my son and daughter-in-law that I was working as a copy boy at the Pueblo Chieftain the night Nixon tried to fire Archibald Cox, the special prosecutor for Watergate.  What is now known as "The Saturday Night Massare".  Nixon had to also fire his Attorney General and Deputy Attorney General, who refused to fire Cox.

Finally Solicitor General Robert Bork, fired Cox.

Today, that seem like cartoon crisis, but at the time it was abusive Executive Power at its most horrific.

Anyway, that I have experienced a major event in a news room of any kind at that moment in history was impressive to them.

I bet @Barry Ancona had a lot of experiences like that, only from a true journalistic position.  Right, Barry?

@Francis
As you know, at 91, I am old enough to be your mother, so take it from one who knows (or thinks she does). Beating up on your body from the outside is not as helpful as stoking good stuff into the inside.   I take vitamins every day, an estrogen tab (yes, men shouldn't do that), a thyroid tab, and that's it. No statins, no BP meds. I eat very little meat, lots of cheese, cereals, vegetables, etc.

Every time I am seen by a new bunch of medicos, I hear (as if they are telling me something new), "You look much younger than (whatever age I am at the time)."  I don't know what to say, because it's really the luck of the draw, and "thank you" seems inappropriate. "Old" is not something that should be an insult.  We'll all get there if we're lucky.

To keep flexibility (no achy joints, except one shoulder), I take collagen with peptides in my morning cereal. Very important. Veg collagen doesn't work, and it's got to be down the hatch.

As for my head, I try not to think about it (very funny, ha ha).  Nobody else in my family lost it, so why should I?

Some things have started getting a little dicey, a lot because of stress about the current "Administration" a.k.a. insanity. (As if I didn't have enough to deal with. No family around here, so it's up to me to get stuff done.  Husband has been legally blind from a medical "mistake" 40 years ago.)

Be well, Francis.  Stop attacking your bod, and so far, your head is fine. Settle down.

@dutchiris
P.S. A habit of moving is vital. Going to the gym is fine, but just keeping moving does more for your body.  Get up. Walk around as you did when you were younger. We have 17 steps in our house and I am up and down them many times a day.  I do the laundry, housework, some of the cooking (hub does the rest), etc.  Move. Set a timer if you need reminding to get up and walk around a bit.  It will become easier as it becomes a habit.  You'll have plenty of time to sit in heaven.

@saarl

They say that it takes 10,000 hours to excel in anything.  So even allotting an entire hour for every day, it would take almost three years just to get 1,000 hours in.  A full 10,000 would take about 27.4 years to reach.

So the fact that you could nearly finish a puzzle that you previously couldn't can mean progress, or simply that you hit a very easy puzzle.

Both can be true at the same time.  Certainly, you're making progress, even if the puzzle was easy.

And you should notice a lot of apparent progress as time progresses, since it seems to the longtime solvers that the difficulty level has been trending downward lately.

But that doesn't mean you aren't getting better.

(Note: ANI DiFranco and ENYA appear regularly here, so commit their names to memory.  The Grand Ole OPRY also appears about twice a year.)

Now, some people like very easy puzzles.  But most of us come here to be puzzled.  As Mr. Spock famously said, "The needs of the many outweigh the needs of the few."  And the many want to see a normal Sunday puzzle.  Getting a too easy puzzle to placate newcomers takes away enjoyment from the rest of us.

Can you see that?

@Steve L - xwstats.com, of course, presents data from a self-selected group of highly interested, highly skilled solvers who represent only a fraction of the NY Times crossword solving community, and the early returns are from those who solve the fastest. I take xwstats.com statistics with a very large grain of salt.

But, in any event, "very easy" does not mean "too easy."
